The image shows two harmonic transverse waves traveling along the positive and negative x-axis. The wave sources are at x = -0.2 m and x = 1.2 m, respectively. Both waves have a speed of 0.4 m/s and an amplitude of 2 m. Particles P and Q at x = 0.2 m and x = 0.8 m start vibrating at time t = 0.

Identify the distance from the source of each wave to the meeting point: For the wave from x = -0.2 m, the distance to the meeting point is 0.2 m. For the wave from x = 1.2 m, the distance to the meeting point is 1.2 m - 0.8 m = 0.4 m.
Calculate the time it takes for each wave to reach the meeting point using the wave speed: Time for the wave from x = -0.2 m: t = 0.2 m / 0.4 m/s = 0.5 s.
Calculate the time it takes for the wave from x = 1.2 m to reach the meeting point: t = 0.4 m / 0.4 m/s = 1 s.
Since the waves start at different times, the meeting time is when both waves reach their respective meeting points: Meeting time: t = 1 s.
